Miles Sound System SDK 6.1c

AIL_waveOutOpen

The function AIL_waveOutOpen assigns a DirectSound object or a Windows Multimedia Extensions (MME) low-level waveOut driver to the Windows MSS API for digital audio performance.

S32 AIL_waveOutOpen(
  HDIGDRIVER *drvr,
  LPHWAVEOUT *lphWaveOut,
  S32 dwDeviceID,
  LPWAVEFORMAT lpFormat
);

In Parameters

dwDeviceID
identifies the waveOut driver to open. Typically, dwDeviceID should be set to 0 or WAVE_MAPPER to specify the first available waveOut driver. Under Win32 with DirectSound, this value specifies a pointer to the GUID of the DirectSound driver to use - you should usually use NULL.
lpFormat
specifies a pointer to a WAVEFORMAT structure that identifies the format of the waveform data to be sent to the waveOut driver. This structure determines the hardware output rate, word size, and channel count, and replaces the functionality of the DIG_USE_STEREO, DIG_USE_16_BITS, and DIG_HARDWARE_SAMPLE_RATE preference values in the DOS API.

Out Parameters

drvr
points to a variable of type HDIGDRIVER, which is typedefed as a pointer to a structure of type DIG_DRIVER. If AIL_waveOutOpen succeeds, a DIG_DRIVER structure will be allocated and initialized, and its address stored in the handle pointed to by *drvr. This address, referred to as a "driver handle" of type HDIGDRIVER, should be passed to other MSS functions which require that a driver be specified.
lphWaveOut
if not NULL, points to a variable of type HWAVEOUT which can be used by the application to communicate directly with the opened waveOut driver, if desired. Most applications do not need to communicate directly with waveOut drivers, so *lphWaveOut should normally be set to NULL. If MSS is using DirectSound, *lphWaveOut should be NULL.

Returns

Zero if the function was successful. Otherwise, a nonzero error code is returned. In the latter case, the AIL_last_error function may be called to obtain a text description of the error. If the call fails under Win32, then you probably don't have DirectSound installed - either install it or set the DIG_USE_WAVEOUT preference to YES.

Discussion

For compatibility with other Miles platforms, you should use the AIL_open_digital_driver function instead of this Windows-only function.

The only reason to use this function instead of AIL_open_digital_driver is if you need to specifically open a particular waveOut or DirectSound device (by setting the dwDeviceID parameter).

If you wish to use this function, you should first become thoroughly familiar with the low-level MME functions waveOutGetNumDevs, waveOutGetDevCaps, and waveOutOpen. These functions permit the identification, selection, and initialization of the desired waveOut drivers. AIL_waveOutOpen takes the place of waveOutOpen and from the application's point of view, the parameters it requires are virtually identical to the MME function it replaces.
